meta.context: If you have been told you have periodontal (gum) disease, you’re not alone.
If you have been told you have periodontal (gum) disease, you’re not alone.
Many adults in the U.S. currently have some form of the disease.

Periodontal diseases range from simple gum inflammation to serious disease that results in major damage to the soft tissue and bone that support the teeth.

Whether your gum disease is stopped, slowed, or gets worse depends a great deal on how well you care for your teeth and gums every day, from this point forward.

head: The dentist, periodontist, or dental hygienist
tail: through a deep-cleaning method called scaling and root planing

meta.context: The dentist, periodontist, or dental hygienist removes the plaque through a deep-cleaning method called scaling and root planing.

head: Root planing
tail: of rough spots on the tooth root where the germs gather

meta.context: Root planing gets rid of rough spots on the tooth root where the germs gather, and helps remove bacteria that contribute to the disease.
Root planing gets rid of rough spots on the tooth root where the germs gather, and helps remove bacteria that contribute to the disease.
In some cases a laser may be used to remove plaque and tartar.

A dentist or periodontist may perform flap surgery to remove tartar deposits in deep pockets or to reduce the periodontal pocket and make it easier for the patient, dentist, and hygienist to keep the area clean.
The gums are then sutured back in place so that the tissue fits snugly around the tooth again.
The gums are then sutured back in place so that the tissue fits snugly around the tooth again.
After surgery the gums will heal and fit more tightly around the tooth.
This sometimes results in the teeth appearing longer.

head: your periodontist or dentist
tail: procedures to help regenerate any bone or gum tissue lost to periodontitis

meta.context: In addition to flap surgery, your periodontist or dentist may suggest procedures to help regenerate any bone or gum tissue lost to periodontitis.

head: natural or synthetic bone
tail: in the area of bone loss

meta.context: Bone grafting, in which natural or synthetic bone is placed in the area of bone loss, can help promote bone growth.
A technique that can be used with bone grafting is called guided tissue regeneration.

head: a small piece of mesh-like material
tail: between the bone and gum tissue

meta.context: In this procedure, a small piece of mesh-like material is inserted between the bone and gum tissue.
This keeps the gum tissue from growing into the area where the bone should be, allowing the bone and connective tissue to regrow.
Growth factors – proteins that can help your body naturally regrow bone – may also be used.

head: your dentist or periodontist
tail: a soft tissue graft, in which synthetic material or tissue taken from another area of your mouth is used to cover exposed tooth roots

meta.context: In cases where gum tissue has been lost, your dentist or periodontist may suggest a soft tissue graft, in which synthetic material or tissue taken from another area of your mouth is used to cover exposed tooth roots.

head: synthetic material or tissue taken from another area of your mouth

meta.context: In cases where gum tissue has been lost, your dentist or periodontist may suggest a soft tissue graft, in which synthetic material or tissue taken from another area of your mouth is used to cover exposed tooth roots.
They can provide you with names of practitioners in your area.
Call the dental school in your area to find out whether it offers this service.
